history.content: The unit ceiling is applied after you've exhausted your number of semesters. If you enter as a first year, you get 8. Transfers get 4. If you study abroad, that doesn't count towards your number of semesters. Within those number of semesters, you can take as many units as you want. If Spring 2017 will be your 4th semester, you should be fine. The unit ceiling plays a role when you need to stay extra semesters to satisfy requirements etc, but have already taken a large number of units. At least this is how I always have understood it. If an instructor could confirm that'd be great, but I'm like 90% sure this is accurate.

children.subject: Also: double majors get an extra semester. But obviously check with your adviser.
Does taking summer classes count as a semester?

history.content:
Hello,

I am a transfer student who is double majoring in CS and Physics. I discovered that after Fall 2016 ( which is my third semester at Cal), I will have 137 units. That is over the unit ceiling. But I planned to take 19-20 units in Spring 2017 to finish the degree on time (i.e. I will have 156-157 units when I graduate). 

My question is, if I have more than 136 total units in Fall 2016, does it mean that I will be "forced" to graduate because of the unit cap ? Must I take 16 or 17 units in Fall , and then taking >20 units in Spring ? I do not want to do summer school next year. What should I do ?
history.subject: Unit Ceiling
